answer_html: Since the series starts at 0, we need 2 terms (the \(\displaystyle n=0\) and \(\displaystyle n=1\) term, specifically).
answer_latex:
Since the
series starts at 0, we need 2 terms (the $\displaystyle n=0$ and
$\displaystyle n=1$ term, specifically).
hints_html:
Use part (a) to find a series representation of the definite integral.

What theorem of series do we have at our disposal that allows us to estimate remainders?

Try to Alternating Series Remainder Theorem.
hints_latex: Use part (a) to find a series representation of the definite integral.

What theorem of series do we have at our disposal that allows us to
estimate remainders?
Try to Alternating Series Remainder Theorem.
hints_raw:
Use part (a) to find a series representation of the definite integral.
What theorem of series do we have at our disposal that allows us to estimate remainders?
Try to Alternating Series Remainder Theorem.
question: 10 (b)
sols_html:
By part (a),

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{1/4} \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx &= \left.\left[\left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}x^{3n+1}\right) + C\right]\right|_0^{1/4} \\ &= \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3n+1}\end{aligned}\]

This is an alternating sum with

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle b_n = \frac{1}{3n+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3n+1}.\end{aligned}\]

Clearly \(\displaystyle b_{n+1} \leq b_n\) and \(\displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty} b_n = 0\). Then by Alternating Series Remainder Theorem, the error in the approximation is bounded as follows:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle |\text{error}| \leq b_{n+1}\end{aligned}\]

Then we are guaranteed the error is less than \(\displaystyle 10^{-5}\) if \(\displaystyle b_{n+1} \leq 10^{-5}\), that is, we must solve

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{1}{3(n+1)+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3(n+1)+1} \leq 10^{-5} = \frac{1}{10^5}.\end{aligned}\]

For \(\displaystyle n+1=1\),

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{1}{3+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3+1} = \frac{1}{4^5} > \frac{1}{10^5}\end{aligned}\]

so we do not have enough terms yet. For \(\displaystyle n+1=2\),

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{1}{3(2)+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3(2)+1} \leq \frac{1}{7}\frac{1}{16000} = \frac{1}{112000} < \frac{1}{10^5}\end{aligned}\]

where we have used \(\displaystyle 4^7 = 2^{14} = 2^{10} \cdot 16 = 1024 \cdot 16 \geq 1000 \cdot 16 = 16000\) to approximate. Thus, \(\displaystyle n+1=2\) is sufficient. Since the series starts at 0, we need 2 terms (the \(\displaystyle n=0\) and \(\displaystyle n=1\) term, specifically).
sols_raw:
By [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH101/April_2013/Question_10_(a)|part (a)]],

:<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
\int_0^{1/4} \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx & = \left.\left[\left(\sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}x^{3n+1}\right) + C\right]\right|_0^{1/4} \\
& = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{(-1)^n}{3n+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3n+1}
\end{align}
</math>

This is an alternating sum with 

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
b_n = \frac{1}{3n+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3n+1}.
</math>

Clearly <math> \displaystyle b_{n+1} \leq b_n</math> and <math> \displaystyle \lim_{n\to\infty} b_n = 0 </math>. Then by Alternating Series Remainder Theorem, the error in the approximation is bounded as follows:

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
|\text{error}| \leq b_{n+1}
</math>

Then we are guaranteed the error is less than <math> \displaystyle 10^{-5} </math> if <math> \displaystyle b_{n+1} \leq 10^{-5} </math>, that is, we must solve

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
 \frac{1}{3(n+1)+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3(n+1)+1} \leq 10^{-5} = \frac{1}{10^5}.
</math>

For <math> \displaystyle n+1=1 </math>,

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
 \frac{1}{3+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3+1} = \frac{1}{4^5} > \frac{1}{10^5}
</math>

so we do not have enough terms yet. For <math> \displaystyle n+1=2 </math>,

:<math> 
\displaystyle 
 \frac{1}{3(2)+1}\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)^{3(2)+1} \leq \frac{1}{7}\frac{1}{16000} = \frac{1}{112000} < \frac{1}{10^5}
</math>

where we have used <math> \displaystyle 4^7 = 2^{14} = 2^{10} \cdot 16 = 1024 \cdot 16 \geq 1000 \cdot 16 = 16000</math> to approximate. Thus, <math> \displaystyle n+1=2 </math> is sufficient. Since the series starts at 0, we need 2 terms (the <math> \displaystyle n=0 </math> and <math> \displaystyle n=1 </math> term, specifically).
statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 4â€“12, justify your answers and show all your work. If a box is provided, write your final answer there. Unless otherwise indicated, simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions.

The power series representation above is used to approximate \(\displaystyle \int_0^{1/4} \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx\). How many terms are required to guarantee that the resulting approximation is within \(\displaystyle 10^{-5}\) of the exact value? Justify your answer.

'''Full-Solution Problems'''. In questions 4–12, justify your answers and '''show all your work'''. If

The power series representation above is used to approximate <math> \displaystyle \int_0^{1/4} \frac{1}{1+x^3} \ dx</math>. How many terms are required to guarantee that the resulting approximation is within <math> \displaystyle 10^{-5} </math> of the exact value? Justify your answer.
